cmdsynopsis.command: sydbox -hv -c pathspec -m magic -E var=val command arg

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: sydbox is a ptrace2 based sandboxing utility for Linux.

listitem.simpara: pathspec to the configuration file, may be repeated. See for more information.
Run a magic command during init, may be repeated. See for more information.
Put var=val in the environment for command, may be repeated
Remove var from the environment for command, may be repeated

refsect1.title: Configuration
refsect1.para: Sydbox is configured through the so-called magic commands. There are three ways to supply magic commands:

listitem.para: Sydbox may be configured using a configuration file. The path to the configuration file is speficied using the -c command line switch or the SYDBOX_CONFIG environment variable. More than one configuration file may be specified this way. However, only the initial configuration file can change the core configuration. If path to the configuration file is prefixed with the character '@', Sydbox looks for this configuration file under $sharedir/sydbox/ where $sharedir is usually /usr/share. The command line switch has precedence over the SYDBOX_CONFIG environment variable.

Sydbox may be configured using magic stat2 calls during runtime. This is achieved by calling stat() system call on the special path /dev/sydbox followed by the magic command. Note that runtime configuration is only possible if the magic lock is unset. The system call stat() was chosen as the magic call because it is practical to invoke using builtin shell commands like:
test -e /dev/sydbox/core/sandbox/read:deny
which enables read sandboxing for a shell running under Sydbox. It is also possible to query certain values using the return value of the magic stat2:
test -e '/dev/sydbox/core/sandbox/read?' && echo "read sandboxing on" || echo "read sandboxing off"
Some of these shell builtins may actually call lstat2 system call instead of stat2 thus Sydbox makes sure to check lstat() system calls for magic commands as well.

refsect2.title: Command Types
refsect2.para: Every magic command accepts an argument of a certain type. The available types are listed below:

listitem.para: A boolean type may have one of the two values, true or false. To specify boolean values when supplying magic commands to Sydbox, you may also use true or false. In addition you can use the short forms t or f and you can also use 1 or 0.
This type represents the basic integer type.
This type represents the basic string type.
This type represents a list of strings. Other types aren't allowed within this type.
This is a special type which is used to make sydbox execute certain functions. It is meant to be used as a basic interprocess communication to workaround some tracing limitations.

note.para: Magic commands of this type can only be used with the magic stat2 system call.

refsect2.title: Specifying Magic Commands
refsect2.para:
As mentioned in Sydbox may be configured using the so-called magic commands. Format of the magic commands is simple:
${PREFIX}/section/of/option${OPERATION_CHARACTER}value
where ${PREFIX} is /dev/sydbox by default (may be altered at compile-time using SYDBOX_MAGIC_PREFIX definition). This prefix is only required for magic stat(), not for -m command line switch.
${OPERATION_CHARACTER} determines the operation of the magic command. Possible values are listed below:

listitem.simpara: This term is used to set a value. Value must be either a boolean, an integer or a string.
This term is used to query a value. Boolean values and certain other values may be queried.
This term is used to append to a string array.
This is used to remove an element from a string array.
This is used to execute a special sydbox command.

refsect2.title: Configuration File Format
refsect2.para: Configuration file format of sydbox is simple. It is just a way to supply many magic commands in a convenient way. All empty lines and lines starting with the number sign '#' are ignored. All the other lines are treated as if they were supplied to Sydbox via the -m command line switch.

refsect2.title: Configuration File Naming
refsect2.para: Configuration file naming of sydbox follows a naming scheme which makes it possible to extract magic command API version from the file name. A sydbox configuration file must have the extension "&SYDBOX_FNAME_EXT;" followed by the API version (e.g. "&SYDBOX_FNAME_EXT;&SYDBOX_API_VERSION;" for API version &SYDBOX_API_VERSION;).
Current magic command API of sydbox version is `&SYDBOX_API_VERSION;'.

refsect2.title: Commands
refsect2.para: Sydbox recognizes the following magic commands:

listitem.para: A string specifying how execve2 system call should be sandboxed. See for more information.
A string specifying how read sandboxing should be done. See for more information.
A string specifying how write sandboxing should be done. See for more information.
A string specifying how network sandboxing should be done. See for more information.

A boolean specifying whether potentially dangerous options to open2 and fcntl2 should be forbidden. These options include O_ASYNC, O_DIRECT and O_SYNC. In addition all fcntl2 commands except F_GETFL, F_SETFL, F_SETOWN, F_SETLK, F_SETLKW, F_SETLK64, F_SETLKW64, F_SETFD, F_GETFD and F_DUPFD are forbidden as well.
A boolean specifying whether writable shared memory mapping ( mmap22 with PROT_WRITE & MAP_SHARED combination ) should be forbidden.

warning.para: This setting is meant as a protection against TOCTOU attacks. However, it should be noted that such attack vectors are relatively diverse under a ptrace() monitoring environment.

listitem.para: A boolean specifying whether per-process directories like /proc/$pid should automatically be whitelisted.
A boolean specifying whether the socket address arguments of successful bind2 calls should be whitelisted for connect2 and sendto2 system calls.

note.para: These socket addresses are whitelisted globally and not per-process for usability reasons. Thus, for example, a process which forks to call bind2 will have its socket address whitelisted for her parent as well.

listitem.para: A boolean specifying whether unknown socket families should be allowed access when network sandboxing is on.
A string specifying the decision to take when an access violation occurs. Possible values are kill, killall and deny. Default is deny which means to deny the system call and resume execution.

An integer specifying the exit code in case core/violation/decision is killall. As a special case, if this integer is equal to zero, sydbox exits with 128 added to the eldest process' exit value in case an access violation has occured. This special case is meant for program tests to check whether an access violation has occured using the exit code.

A boolean specifying whether certain failures like errors during path resolution should be treated as access violations. Note this is just a switch for reporting, the access to the system call is denied nevertheless.

A boolean specifying whether certain violations which are considered safe should be reported. For example, mkdir2 is a system call which fails when it can not create an existant directory. In this special case, sydbox denies the system call with EEXIST for consistency and does not raise an access violation in case core/violation/raise_safe is set to false. Other examples are, the access2 system call which is silently denied with EACCES and listxattr2, and llistxattr2 system calls which are silently denied with ENOTSUP if this option is set to false.
A boolean specifying whether Sydbox should follow forks, vforks and clones.
A boolean specifying whether traced processes should be killed when Sydbox exits.

note.para: This is supported on Linux-3.8 or newer via PTRACE_O_EXITKILL.

listitem.para: A string specifying the state of the magic lock. Possible values are on, off and exec. If magic lock is on no magic commands are allowed. Note, the magic lock is tracked per-process. If exec is specified, the magic lock is set to on when the process returns from the system call execve2.
A boolean specifying whether seccomp user-mode filters should be used. This works only on Linux-3.5 or newer and sydbox must be compiled with the --enable-seccomp configure option.
A boolean specifying whether sydbox should use the new ptrace requests PTRACE_SEIZE and PTRACE_INTERRUPT to trace processes.
A boolean specifying whether sydbox should use a hack to determine working directories under a path longer than PATH_MAX.
A boolean specifying the case sensitivity of pattern matching.

A string specifying how to match patterns with no '*' or '?' characters in them. Possible values are literal and prefix. With literal such patterns are matched literally, whereas with prefix Sydbox appends /*** to the end of such patterns to make them a prefix match. Implemented mostly to provide compatibility with sydbox-0 patterns.

This setting specifies a list of path patterns. If one of these patterns matches the resolved path of an execve2 system call, the process in question is resumed. See for more information on wildmatch patterns.

note.para:
The initial execve2 is not checked. Thus, if sydbox is called like:
$> sydbox -m exec/resume_if_match+/bin/sh -- /bin/sh
she will not execute the /bin/sh command.

This functionality does not work with seccomp because once enabled, seccomp mode can not be disabled. If sydbox detaches from the process all observed system calls of the process will fail with ENOSYS. Due to this fact upon receiving this command when seccomp is enabled sydbox goes on to trace the process but stops sandboxing and frees all sandboxing related data structures of the process. The process is ignored. However, this workaround may not be enough for some cases, for example, when the process in question is a daemon and must resume its execution after sydbox exits. For such cases use cmd/exec.

listitem.para: This setting specifies a list of path patterns. If one of these patterns matches the resolved path of an execve2 system call, the process in question is killed. See for more information on wildmatch patterns.

note.para:
The initial execve2 is not checked. Thus, if sydbox is called like:
$> sydbox -m exec/kill_if_match+/bin/sh -- /bin/sh
she will execute the /bin/sh command.

listitem.para: Specifies a list of path patterns to filter for execve2 sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to filter for read sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to filter for write sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of network addresses to filter for network sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to whitelist for execve2 sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to whitelist for read sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to whitelist for write sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of network addresses to whitelist for bind2 network sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of network addresses to whitelist for connect2 and sendto2 network sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to blacklist for execve2 sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to blacklist for read sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of path patterns to blacklist for write sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of network addresses to blacklist for bind2 network sandboxing. See and .
Specifies a list of network addresses to blacklist for connect2 and connect2 network sandboxing. See and .

Makes sydbox execute an external command without sandboxing. The program name and arguments must be separated with the US (unit separator, octal: 037) character. sydfmt1 may be used to do this. Consult its manual page for more information.

note.para: This command can only be used with the magic stat2 system call.

refsect1.title: Sandboxing

listitem.para: Sandboxing is off, none of the relevant system calls are checked and all access is allowed.
Sandboxing defaults to deny, whitelists can be used to allow access.
Sandboxing defaults to allow, blacklists can be used to deny access.

refsect1.para: In addition, there are filters for every sandboxing to prevent Sydbox from reporting an access violation. Note, access is still denied in such cases.

refsect2.title: Write Sandboxing
refsect2.para: This sandboxing checks certain system calls for filesystem write access. If a system call tries to write, modify or change attributes of a path, this attempt is reported and the system call is denied. There are two ways to customize this behaviour. Sydbox may be configured to "whitelist" some path patterns. If the path argument of the system call which is subject to be modified matches a pattern in the list of whitelisted path patterns, this attempt is not denied. Additionally, Sydbox may be configured to "filter" some path patterns. In this case a match will prevent Sydbox from reporting a warning about the access violation, the system call is still denied though.

List of observed system calls are: access2, faccessat2, chmod2, fchmodat2, chown2, chown322, lchown2, lchown322, fchownat2, open2, openat2, creat2, mkdir2, mkdirat2, mknod2, mknodat2, rmdir2, truncate2, truncate642, mount2, umount2, umount22, utime2, utimes2, utimensat2, futimesat2, unlink2, unlinkat2, link2, linkat2, rename2, renameat2, symlink2, symlinkat2, setxattr2, lsetxattr2, removexattr2, and lremovexattr2.

refsect2.title: Read Sandboxing
refsect2.para: This sandboxing checks certain system calls for filesystem read access. If a system call tries to read a path, this attempt is reported and the system call is denied. See for more information on how to customize this behaviour.
List of observed system calls are: access2, faccessat2, open2, openat2, listxattr2, and llistxattr2.

refsect2.title: execve(2) Sandboxing
refsect2.para: This sandboxing denies execve2 calls in case the path argument does not match one of the whitelisted patterns. Note, all exec3 family functions are sandboxed because these functions are just wrappers of the execve2 system call.

refsect2.title: Network Sandboxing
refsect2.para: This sandboxing exposes a way to prevent unwanted network calls. The observed system calls are: bind2, connect2, and sendto2. To increase usability, these system calls are observed in two groups: bind and connect. bind2 belongs to the first group, whereas the other two system calls belong to the connect group.

refsect1.title: Pattern Matching
refsect1.para: Sydbox uses shell-style pattern matching for whitelists and filters. The wildmatching code is borrowed from rsync and behaves like:

listitem.para: A '*' matches any path component, but it stops at slashes.
Use '**' to match anything, including slashes.
A '?' matches any character except a slash (/).
A "[" introduces a character class, such as [a-z] or [[:alpha:]].
In a wildcard pattern, a backslash can be used to escape a wildcard character, but it is matched literally when no wildcards are present.
A trailing "dir_name/***" will match both the directory (as if "dir_name/" had been specified) and everything in the directory (as if "dir_name/**" had been specified).

note.simpara: Sydbox checks patterns from multiple sources. There is no precedence between different sources, and the last matching pattern decides the outcome.

refsect1.title: Address Matching
refsect1.para: Sydbox has a simple address scheme to match network addresses. The addresses can be in the following forms:

listitem.para: Specifies a UNIX socket path, ${PATTERN} specifies a path pattern. See for more information on path patterns.
Specifies an abstract UNIX socket path, ${PATTERN} specifies a path pattern. See for more information on path patterns.
Specifies an IPV4 address. For more information, read the paragraph below.
Specifies an IPV6 address. For more information, read the paragraph below.

refsect1.para: /${NETMASK} may be omitted from inet: and inet6: addresses and ${PORT_RANGE} can in two forms: either an integer or a service name from the services5 database. Either as as a single entity or as a range in the form BEGIN-END.
In addition there are some aliases, you may use instead of specifying an address:

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: Below are examples of invocation and configuration of Sydbox.

refsect2.title: Invocation Examples
refsect2.para:
Allow all reads, deny read access to /etc/shadow:
$> sydbox -E LC_ALL=POSIX \ -m core/sandbox/read:allow \ -m blacklist/read+/etc/shadow \ -- /bin/sh -c 'cat /etc/shadow' sydbox@3141592653: -- Access Violation! -- sydbox@3141592653: process id=20926 (abi=0 name:`cat') sydbox@3141592653: cwd: `/home/alip' sydbox@3141592653: cmdline: `cat /etc/shadow' sydbox@3141592653: open(`/etc/shadow') cat: /etc/shadow: Operation not permitted $>

Deny all reads and writes, allow read access to /dev/zero and write access to /dev/full. The executable dd is not static in this case thus allow access to /lib64 where it will load its shared libraries from as well:

note.para: On the system of the author the dd binary links only to libraries under /lib64, use ldd to check the linked libraries on your system.

note.simpara: Note the quoting to escape shell expansion.

refsect2.programlisting: $> sydbox -E LC_ALL=POSIX \ -m core/sandbox/read:deny \ -m core/sandbox/write:deny \ -m 'whitelist/read+/lib64/***' \ -m whitelist/read+/dev/zero \ -m whitelist/read+/dev/full \ -- dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/full count=1 dd: writing to '/dev/full': No space left on device 1+0 records in 0+0 records out 0 bytes (0 B) copied, 0.000447024 s, 0.0 kB/s $>

note.para: The initial execve is not checked.

refsect2.programlisting: $> sydbox -E LC_ALL=POSIX \ -m exec/kill_if_match+/usr/bin/ktorrent \ -m exec/kill_if_match+/usr/bin/rtorrent \ -- /bin/sh -c ktorrent sydbox@3141592653: callback_exec: kill_if_match pattern=`/usr/bin/ktorrent' matches execve path=`/usr/bin/ktorrent' sydbox@3141592653: callback_exec: killing process:3097 [abi:0 cwd:`/home/alip']
refsect2.para:
Execute a process without sandboxing so it will continue execution after sandboxing:
$> ./sydbox -- sh -c 'stat "$(./sydfmt exec echo hello world)"' hello world File: /dev/sydbox/cmd/exec!echo\037hello\037world Size: 0 Blocks: 0 IO Block: 512 character special file Device: 0h/0d Inode: 0 Links: 0 Device type: 1,3 Access: (0666/crw-rw-rw-) Uid: ( 0/ root) Gid: ( 0/ root) $>

refsect1.title: Signals
refsect1.para: Sydbox dumps information about the traced process tree to standard error upon receiving the SIGUSR1 signal. Send SIGUSR2 signal for more verbose process information.

refsect1.title: Notes
refsect1.para: This manual page was written for sydbox version `&SYDBOX_VERSION;'. This version is considered unstable.

refsect1.title: Bugs
refsect1.para: This is unstable software and should be used with care. Report bugs by direct mail to alip@exherbo.org

refsect1.title: Security
refsect1.para: Sydbox is not designed to be used as a security measure. There are many ways to circumvent the sandbox. Use this for diagnosing or debugging.
